column4: Hi all, for quite some year I've been compiling my own kernels, at least a year with make-kpkg under debian and now under breezy. But now, either I am doing something wrong or there might be a bug in "kernel-package
I get lots of modprobe errors while booting the initrd image
when I manually open the initrd file and execute a depmod -a, rebuild the initrd image, everything works fine
I have to add: I use the kernel from kernel.org, not the [k] ubuntu packages
am I the only one to experience this behavior?
do you need an initrd?
I just use my custom kernel/modules and no initrd
seems so in order to keep the splash
right
I used to do it that way to, but i kind of like the splash
personally I just went with bootsplash instead
seems as if the depmod -a after building the kernel is missing... because all the modules.* files are missing in the initrd
never tried that one, is it comparable to [k] ubuntu splash?
well you need to pathc the kernel. no big deal though
patching is not the issue...
just like to keep it simple and nice (thats why I switched to [k] ubuntu)
then you get a nice 16bit color 1024x768 boot screen
and you just make the splash initrd with the utility that comes with it. it doesn't depend on anything but the kernel patch
cool, will try that, thanks
is there a way to get something between all boot messages (verbose) and silent? like it is done in [k] ubuntu?
I don't know how that looks. it support ttf text messages and animations that can be executed from the init scripts
for example you could show animated connecting computers when the network comes up or display a text message in color
you can also get a progress bar
ok, then I will have a closer look at it
